message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Vote: draft Translator's Preface now or after?">
The author asks: should the translator write a draft of the Translator's Preface NOW (before full translation begins) to capture all the decisions while they're fresh — with the understanding it will be revised after translation is complete? Or should we wait until after?

Reply "NOW" or "AFTER" with a brief reason.
</teammate-message>

input.content: NOW — The decisions that need to be captured are at peak clarity right now: the 境/Jing transliteration rationale, the -scape system, the 德 split convention, the 形而上/形而上学 distinction, the 虚无 ≠ 空 firewall, the "experiential sequences are load-bearing" principle, the bilingual structure, the five registers. These are architectural decisions. If we wait until after translation, the translator will have to reconstruct the reasoning from scattered Q-files and memo notes, and some of the deliberative nuance will be lost. A draft now also serves as a working reference document during translation — the translator can check their own rationale when edge cases arise. Buddhist translation precedent: Xuanzang's translation bureau wrote methodological prefaces before beginning sutra translation, precisely to fix principles while the reasoning was fresh. The preface will naturally need revision after translation (specific examples, page references, adjustments based on what emerged in practice), but the core architecture should be captured now.
input.summary: NOW — capture decisions at peak clarity, revise later
